name: Prime Coordinate Map
description: The mathematical function that assigns to each object its vector of prime exponents, creating a homomorphism from the multiplicative structure of objects to the additive structure of vector space.
text:
The prime-coordinate map is a fundamental mathematical function that provides the bridge between objects in a factorization domain and their representation as coordinate vectors. This mapping, denoted as φ, is at the heart of the UOR framework's ability to represent complex objects in a structured coordinate system.

For any object x in a domain with unique factorization, the prime-coordinate map φ assigns to x its vector of prime exponents. If x has the prime factorization x = p₁^e₁ · p₂^e₂ · ... · pₙ^eₙ (where each pᵢ is a prime and eᵢ is its exponent), then φ(x) is the vector (e₁, e₂, ..., eₙ). In more general terms, φ(x) maps each prime p to its exponent in the factorization of x.

The result of this mapping is a vector in what is called the exponent space. For objects with finite prime factorizations, this space is typically Z^P, where Z is the set of integers and P is the set of relevant primes. Each dimension of this space corresponds to a specific prime, and the coordinate along that dimension represents the exponent of that prime in the object's factorization.

A crucial property of the prime-coordinate map is that it is a homomorphism, specifically φ(x·y) = φ(x) + φ(y). This means that multiplication of objects corresponds to addition of their coordinate vectors. This homomorphic property is what enables the transformation from a multiplicative structure to an additive one, greatly simplifying many mathematical operations and analyses.

The prime-coordinate map is built upon the foundation of unique factorization. Because each object has a unique prime factorization (up to reordering and units), the mapping to coordinate vectors is well-defined and consistent. This ensures that the coordinate representation captures the intrinsic structure of objects rather than artifacts of a particular representation method.
mathExpression: x = p_1^{e_1} \cdot p_2^{e_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n^{e_n} \implies \phi(x) = (e_1, e_2, \ldots, e_n)
